title: ‚ÄúSimple... hard discipline‚Äù: Cardi B praises disciplined Stefon Diggs in Patriots win
description: Rapper Cardi B credited New England Patriots receiver Stefon Diggs with "hard discipline" following his team's win against the Denver Broncos.
fullText:
‚ÄúSimple... hard discipline‚Äù: Cardi B praises disciplined Stefon Diggs in Patriots win originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The New England Patriots defeated the Denver Broncos 10-7 to claim the AFC Championship amid freezing temperatures.

Wide receiver Stefon Diggs advanced to his first Super Bowl following the gritty victory, prompting an emotional celebration from his girlfriend, Grammy-winning rapper Cardi B, in the owner's suite. The haymaker came on kicker Andy Borregales‚Äô 23-yard field goal in the third quarter, a 23-yard dart through the falling snow that provided the ultimate margin of victory. While the snowfall in Denver created a difficult environment for the players and the fans in attendance, the Patriots secured their 12th Super Bowl appearance in franchise history.

Overall, the Patriots offense relied on a punishing 16-play drive ‚Äì consuming nine minutes and 53 seconds of the clock ‚Äì effectively grounding a Broncos attack that struggled to find rhythm in the adverse conditions. Diggs recorded five receptions for 17 yards during the low-scoring affair. Quarterback Drake Maye served as the statistical engine of the team during the game in Denver. Maye finished with 65 rushing yards and scored the only touchdown for the Patriots, navigating the snow with precision.

Stefon Diggs mutually parted ways with the Houston Texans after a one-year stint in 2025. However, it appears that his decision to sign a three-year contract with New England in March has paid dividends. The victory represents the first Super Bowl trip for Diggs in his career, vindication after he previously lost conference championship games while playing for the Minnesota Vikings and the Buffalo Bills.

MORE:¬†3 reasons Patriots defense dominated in AFC playoffs ‚Äî and can keep it up in Super Bowl 60

Cardi B was one of the thousands of Patriots fans who were tuned in for what became Diggs' first conference championship victory after multiple attempts. Apart from being a featured presence on the official Patriots Instagram account, the Grammy-winner‚Äôs appearance in the owner's suite marked another high-profile show of support now that the team has officially advanced. Over the past several months, the rapper has stood by Diggs' side as the veteran receiver navigated through a difficult recovery period following an ACL injury.

She shared her feelings with NFL Network reporter Cameron Wolfe after the win. The rapper described the pride she felt watching the receiver return from his injury, saying:

"I'm feeling very excited, I'm very happy for him, very proud of him,‚Äù Cardi B said. ‚ÄúHe just came back from an ACL, and me seeing the progress and the process of him going through there, from the first time he started running back."

Cardi B life as a football girlie going well @iamcardib

Our 1-on-1 chat as Stefon Diggs ‚Äúhard work and discipline‚Äù journey leads him to Super Bowl. pic.twitter.com/vJnpEFl2rA

‚Äî Cameron Wolfe (@CameronWolfe) January 26, 2026

Cardi B attributed the success of Diggs to his personal discipline and work ethic. There is no more disciplined athlete, maybe in the current locker room of the Patriots, than Stefon Diggs. She said:

"Discipline. Discipline and work. It's not like, oh, you wake up and you great. It's... it's discipline. It's going to bed early. It's go... waking up early. It's... it's not missing one day of work, nothing. It's discipline. Simple... hard discipline."

The rapper confirmed her relationship with Diggs in June and gave birth to their son in November, since becoming a regular at games. Wolfe mentioned that Diggs helped Cardi B transition into being a fan of the sport, referring to the rapper as a member of the "brigade" of Patriots supporters. She wore a Patriots cap and had green hair while attending the game in Denver. She said:

"Not at all. I mean, I'm a... I'm a big baseball fan. I'm a Red Sox fan. Everybody knows I'm a Red Sox fan. So... it's kind of cool that we keeping it... in New England."

New England will face the Seattle Seahawks in Super Bowl 60 on Jan. 25. The Seahawks advanced after winning the NFC Championship game on the same day. Diggs was emotional after the victory and noted the team had more work to finish.

Malcolm Butler's Super Bowl INT flashbacks begin ahead of Patriots-Seahawks rematch

Teams, odds, spread and more for 2026 Super Bowl matchup

title: Why NFL fans believe 'script writers' predicted Super Bowl 60 matchup with preseason graphic
description: The Super Bowl 60 matchup was unpredictable. Or was it?
fullText:
Why NFL fans believe 'script writers' predicted Super Bowl 60 matchup with preseason graphic originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

For a few years, there existed a conspiracy theory that the colors of the Super Bowl logo predicted which two teams would play for the Lombardi Trophy.

Well, that one is out, and a new theory is in.

Some NFL fans believe a preseason graphic the league posted to its social media accounts actually predicted the seemingly unpredictable Super Bowl 60 matchup between the New England Patriots and Seattle Seahawks, two teams that hadn't won a playoff game since 2019 before this season.

Here's a look at the graphic behind the NFL's newest "script writer" conspiracy theory.

MORE:Super Bowl 60 odds, spread as Seahawks open as favorites

After the Patriots and Seahawks punched their ticket to the Super Bowl, fans started to notice which two quarterbacks seem to be closer to the giant Lombardi Trophy than the rest in this graphic posted by the NFL on the first day of the regular season:

‚Äî RedditCFB (@RedditCFB) January 26, 2026

A closer inspection reveals you can make the case Baker Mayfield was actually closer than Darnold, or that Travis Hunter seems to be the closest to the trophy.

This is no time for facts, though. NFL fans have unearthed the latest grand Super Bowl conspiracy, and it's true that Maye and Darnold were both front and center in relation to the Lombardi Trophy in the graphic just as they are in reality today.

"They really gave us the script in September," the lead Drake Maye fan account tweeted Sunday night.

They really gave us the script in September https://t.co/ofeVgBdbPb

‚Äî Drake Maye Lover (@drakemayeloverr) January 26, 2026

Another look at the graphic reveals the NFL probably believed a Patriots-Seahawks Super Bowl was enormously unlikely. The sport's biggest names are front-and-center, from Saquon Barkley and Patrick Mahomes to Brock Purdy and Joe Burrow. Lamar Jackson and Josh Allen are also closer to Mahomes and Barkley than they are to Maye and Darnold in the distance.

Considering players from the Jacksonville Jaguars, New York Giants and Tennessee Titans are standing nearly shoulder-to-shoulder with Maye and Darnold in the distance, it seems more like the league discounted the Patriots and Seahawks than predicted their Super Bowl 60 meeting.

Why let the finer details get in the way of a good conspiracy theory, though?

Seahawks Pope trend continues with Super Bowl 60 berth

title: Being in WSL is a privilege not a right ‚Äì relegation risk should be taken seriously
description: The boos lurch up from the Lower Gladys end. Guttural, albeit technically premature, 45 seconds-ish too quick for the final whistle. Not that you can blame the Everton faithful for wanting to call it quits on this drab 1-0 Women‚Äôs Super League defeat to Brighton & Hove Albion, Everton‚Äôs ninth loss of the season and their sixth at home. Sometimes that familiar chemical instinct just takes over, the brain telling the body to commit and just make it stop. There‚Äôs something to be said for keeping he
fullText:
The boos lurch up from the Lower Gladys end. Guttural, albeit technically premature, 45 seconds-ish too quick for the final whistle.

Not that you can blame the Everton faithful for wanting to call it quits on this drab 1-0 Women‚Äôs Super League defeat to Brighton & Hove Albion, Everton‚Äôs ninth loss of the season and their sixth at home. Sometimes that familiar chemical instinct just takes over, the brain telling the body to commit and just make it stop.

There‚Äôs something to be said for keeping heritage alive, that even the ‚ÄòGoodison Boo‚Äô won‚Äôt be condemned to sepia-tint without a fight. We can still get angry here, fellas. There‚Äôs another thing to be said altogether about those boos returning so soon after the early-season promise of new hope and new chapters.

As of Sunday night, following victories for Liverpool and West Ham over Tottenham Hotspur and Leicester City, Brian Sorensen‚Äôs side sit third-from-bottom in the WSL, one point above bottom Liverpool, level on points with West Ham United and a point off Leicester above them.

Maybe The Athletic is overreacting. But it feels many have forgotten there is a threat of relegation this season, that, with the WSL‚Äôs expansion from 12 to 14 teams and the promotion play-off between the bottom-placed WSL side and third-placed WSL2 side. For whatever reason, the spectre of the latter has been met in press boxes and boardrooms with a shrug, another shrug, some WSL-WSL2 equivalent of, ‚ÄúLads, it‚Äôs Tottenham‚Äù.

Yet, it was clear on Friday night from those in the Goodison stands that they weren‚Äôt underplaying the risk, nor those Liverpool fans at St Helens on Sunday, twirling their red-and-white striped scarves over their heads at having finally tasted the sweet lacquer of league victory this season following their 2-0 win over Tottenham Hotspur.

And it was these scenes, so disparate in their respective anguish and relief, that should serve as a reminder to those running these clubs that the threat of relegation is very real.

The gap between the top of WSL2 and the bottom of WSL has, in recent history, been more precarious than conquerable, the financial buy-in required to compete not worth the pay-off for most ownerships. Yet, this January, WSL2 teams at the top are bolstering their ranks, fuelled by the knowledge that if there is a time to get in on this women‚Äôs football deal, now is it. Two WSL2 win an automatic pass to the top. The third wins a one-off showdown on home turf with the bottom-placed WSL side.

The latter is a prospect that has emboldened rather than deterred. Former top-flight sides Bristol City and Crystal Palace, seven and eight points behind leaders Charlton Athletic, have both been busy securing players with WSL experience.

Birmingham City, five points behind Charlton, spent a reported second-tier record ¬£270,000 ($370,000) to sign midfielder Wilma Leidhammar from Norrkoping.

Three and a half years ago, such a fee would have been a world record.

Now, it‚Äôs a benchmark for second-tier ambition.

It is also a timely warning to WSL teams who forget that the top-flight is a privilege, not a right.

Liverpool have, for their part, heeded this, spending more than ¬£1million in the January transfer window on an encouraging array of future promise and present impact. Three of those players ‚Äì goalkeeper Jennifer Falk, midfielder Denise O‚ÄôSullivan (brought in for a club-record fee of ¬£300,000 from North Carolina Courage) and Aurelie Csillag ‚Äì were instrumental in Sunday‚Äôs victory.

A big January had always been the plan, taking a half-season to adjust to a new playing style under new management, to give new recruitment head Rob Clarkson, who joined in the summer, time to gauge where the additional stitching was required before committing to any wholesale changes.

Yet, before kick-off on Sunday at St Helen‚Äôs, there still skulked a jittery energy in the press room and in the terraces, an understanding that the prevailing winds needed changing and fast. While the gap in quality between the WSL and WSL2 is still notable, momentum and morale can play a part.

The same realisation slowly permeated around Goodison at full time on Friday night. The Everton hierarchy‚Äôs vision for this season did not include injuries to key players such as captain Megan Finnigan and forward Katja Snoeijs, the departure of CEO Hannah Forshaw after less than a year in the role, or the ongoing transfer row with France striker Kelly Gago, whom Everton made their highest-paid player in the summer.

But there is a recognition internally that performances under Sorensen, often laborious with players unable to execute tactical nuances, have not been good enough. There is also recognition that Everton remain a work in progress and that the persistent calls to the new ownership for more investment in the squad ‚Äì whose budget is the second-lowest in the WSL for the third successive season, according to sources ‚Äì can‚Äôt keep being ignored.

And perhaps that is what is needed: the sharpening of vision, the cold-blooded rush of survival mode.

Before the season began, there was an acknowledgement among senior figures at numerous WSL clubs that the watermark for existence had risen, that getting by would require more pocket-digging. Six months later, there is a growing understanding that those earlier projections were actually lowballed, that valuations and fees are rising more quickly than had been imagined.

Even without the threat of relegation, Everton fans‚Äô discontent is understandable. According to Opta, only at Arsenal‚Äôs Meadow Park (no wins) and Manchester City‚Äôs Joie Stadium (no wins) do Everton have a worse win rate than at Goodison Park (10 per cent).

If a WSL team finds itself on the sorry end of the promotion play-off, it will boil down to a failure to take the tide seriously, to sitting slack-jawed in the directors box as the walls cave in and those clubs around you nab yet another player off your wishlist.

Because that is where the stench of relegation begins to waft, eventually latching onto a depleted bench and another lacklustre backwards pass.

This article originally appeared in The Athletic.

Liverpool, Everton, Women's Soccer

2026 The Athletic Media Company

title: Sam Darnold Shares Blunt Health Update as Seahawks QB Addresses Personal Struggles Before Super Bowl
description: Sam Darnold isn‚Äôt sugarcoating anything heading into the Super Bowl after the Seattle Seahawks‚Äò 31-27 win over the Los Angeles Rams. The QB offered a blunt update while opening up about health and personal challenges.
fullText:
Sam Darnold isn‚Äôt sugarcoating anything heading into the Super Bowl after the Seattle Seahawks‚Äò 31-27 win over the Los Angeles Rams. The QB offered a blunt update while opening up about health and personal challenges.

‚ÄúNot really, I think, I‚Äôve actually talked to my teammates about this, but I think we, middle of the season, week nine or ten, I think it might have been a bigger problem,‚Äù he said, via ESPN‚Äòs Brady Henderson‚Äôs post on X. ‚ÄúBut with all the reps that we‚Äôve accumulated throughout the season and throughout training camp, OTAs, all that stuff, I wasn‚Äôt really concerned about timing or anything like that on certain reps.‚Äù

Sam Darnold also spoke about playing through injury for a second straight week. He said he felt good physically and didn‚Äôt view it as a major setback.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs almost poetic for Cougar Cup the way that one does,‚Äù he said.

This is developing news. Stay tuned.

title: 49ers have only 1 clear option for franchise tag in 2026
description: There are a slew of San Francisco 49ers free agents eligible for a franchise tag, but only one player makes sense to use it on.
fullText:
It's rare that the San Francisco 49ers use their franchise tag during an offseason. We may see that rare occurrence in 2026.

There are 21 players eligible for franchise tags among the 49ers' 2026 free agents. Among those 21, only kicker Eddy Pineiro stands out as a real candidate for the tag.

General manager John Lynch and head coach Kyle Shanahan have typically been conservative about using the team's franchise tag on pending free agents, opting instead to either sign them to long-term deals or trade them for draft capital.

The only time they've used a franchise tag since taking over as the GM and head coach in 2017 was in 2019 when kicker Robbie Gould was set to hit free agency. Gould held out for a long-term deal and ultimately agreed to a four-year, $19 million deal with $10.5 million guaranteed instead of playing on the one-year, $5 million tag.

We may see something similar this offseason, although it's unclear whether Pineiro would hold out the same way Gould did.

After joining the 49ers in Week 2, Pineiro went 28-for-29 on field goal tries in the regular season with his only miss coming on a 64-yard try that hit the crossbar. He was also a perfect three-for-three in the postseason. Given the 49ers' kicking woes it would make sense that they'll aim to keep Pineiro in the building.

The only other player who might receive a franchise tag is wide receiver Jauan Jennings, but Over the Cap projects the tag for a wide receiver to clear $28 million for one year. San Francisco may desire a reunion with Jennings. They're likely ready to pass at that exorbitant price tag.

That opens the door for the 49ers to use their tag on Pineiro to ensure some stability at the kicker position for at least one year with the chance of making him their kicker for the foreseeable future.

More 49ers: Grading the 49ers' 2025 rookie class after elimination

This article originally appeared on Niners Wire: 49ers free agents: K Eddy Pineiro a franchise tag candidate

title: By the Numbers: Purdue 82 Illinois 88
description: Purdue played an overall great game against the Illini but it was to no avail as Keaton Wagler had one of the greatest performances in Mackey Arena history on the way to an 88-82 victory for Illinois. It was an unfortunate loss for a team that has struggled to maintain leads in the last several [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
Purdue played an overall great game against the Illini but it was to no avail as Keaton Wagler had one of the greatest performances in Mackey Arena history on the way to an 88-82 victory for Illinois. It was an unfortunate loss for a team that has struggled to maintain leads in the last several games that have led to lots of questions from fans and pundits alike about Purdue‚Äôs ability to win the B1G and make a run in March. Can the Boilers get back on track? They‚Äôll have a big opportunity to do so Tuesday night against Indiana inside Assembly Hall.

Let‚Äôs take a look at the loss to the Illini ‚ÄòBy the Numbers.‚Äô

It was an historic day for Illinois‚Äô star freshman. Keaton Wagler entered the game against Purdue as the Illini‚Äôs leading scorer at 15.3ppg and tabbed as a possible lottery draft pick in the 2026 NBA Draft. Wagler elevated himself into rarified air with an amazing 46 point performance that showed the 6‚Äô6 guard may just be moving towards B1G player of the year and first team All-American.

Keaton Wagler scored the most points EVER by a visitor at Mackey üò±:

46 PTS
13-17 FG
9-11 3PT

WOW. pic.twitter.com/KVAd0B0W0A

‚Äî NCAA March Madness (@MarchMadnessMBB) January 24, 2026

Mackey Arena is typically a place where the best players can often struggle to get going. Steph Curry visited and found it difficult to do much of anything with Chris Kramer and the Paint Crew hounding him all game long. What kind of history did Wagler make? He now owns the highest single game scoring record for any opponent inside Mackey Arena and the third highest in any venue in Purdue‚Äôs entire program history.

Simply put: This is what other teams felt like when Carsen Edwards would show up and hit everything once he crossed halfcourt.

Wagler‚Äôs performance was an all-time great one but Braden Smith had himself a day as well. The senior guard started off a little slow but when the Boilers needed someone to match Wagler‚Äôs scoring, he showed why he is likely to be a first team All American and win the Bob Cousy Award again. Smith would go for 27 points and 12 assists on just 1 turnover while playing 37 minutes and those three minutes were largely because he sprained his ankle in the second half.

Braden Smith today:
27 points
3 rebounds
12 assists
1 steal
69% FG
2/3 3PM

#4 Purdue lost to #11 Illinois by 6 pic.twitter.com/LhOii0TwI3

‚Äî Daily Basketball Statlines (@DailyNBAStats) January 25, 2026

Smith has continued to be stellar but simply isn‚Äôt getting the help he needs from teammates, specifically his fellow seniors in TKR and Loyer. Purdue still has the ability to attain their goals but it won‚Äôt happen with those two not playing up to what they should be as seniors.

Omer Mayer came to Purdue as a player who was known to have a bit of scorers touch to his game that may be above his age. He flashed that for Israel at FIBA and seemingly in the preseason but the season started off rather rough from behind the arc. That hasn‚Äôt deterred Mayer up to this point as he has played really good defense and seemingly continued to contribute in almost any other way.

In the first 12 games, Mayer struggled from nearly everywhere on the floor. The freshman shot just 30/77 (39%) from the floor and 11/41 (26.8%) from behind the arc. He isn‚Äôt expected to be a primary scorer but being someone who can clearly generate his own shot and showing an ability to catch and shoot lifts Purdue‚Äôs offense. In the last eight games though, Mayer has turned it around.

Lost in that half: Omer Mayer being the best overseas pro in a game full of them. Those two threes were really important for #Purdue.

‚Äî Brian Neubert ‚Äî GoldandBlack.com (@brianneubert) January 24, 2026

Mayer has seemingly found his form, shooting 10/19 from behind the arc for 52.6% while averaging 1.1 turnovers. That‚Äôs a big key for a player who will definitely shoulder a bigger scoring load next season. That need was seen somewhat after Smith went to the bench with an ankle sprain and Mayer responded with 5 points, 1 rebound, and 1 assist in short span where he was needed more. He is actually scoring less but is much more efficient.

It isn‚Äôt often that Purdue over the last 40 years is utterly dominated on the glass like it was against the Illini. A 14 rebound advantage of 33-19 is one thing but giving up 13 offensive rebounds that led to an 18-2 advantage in second chance points was devastating. Purdue had less turnovers, converted those into points (more on that later), and shot 57% from the field. Allowing the Illini to break their spirit on the glass was the one things that it couldn‚Äôt afford to let happen with Wagler‚Äôs performance.

That minus fourteen rebounding mark is the worst performance for Purdue since they did the same against Illinois on January 21st, 2020.

Purdue once again showed their ability in handling the ball in a high level manner by only turning the ball over for a program tying record (for a second time this season) of just three times. On the flipside, the Illini turned it over just ten times but Purdue converted those into 20 points. Purdue was +17 in that regard and it helped offset the rebounding and second chance scoring advantage the Illini had.

Nobody is going to question the impact that Fletcher Loyer can have on a basketball game. He is rarely in the wrong position on defense and always seems to be in the right place on offense. The issue over the last several games is that where he brings the most value on the offensive end as a dead-eye shooter and offensive mis-match just isn‚Äôt happening.

Purdue needs more out of Fletcher Loyer. 

Averaging just 6.0 PPG in his last three games while shooting a combined 5-20 from the field and 2-12 from three-point range during that span. 

The Boilers can't go back to the Final Four with Loyer playing like this.

‚Äî Jon Rothstein (@JonRothstein) January 25, 2026

Over the last nine games, Loyer is shooting just 14/54 for 25.9% from behind the arc. In fact, this is probably the most difficult stretch of shooting Loyer has endured in his career at Purdue. The frustrating thing is that Loyer is playing at a high level everywhere else for the Boilers but his ability to make threes is what gives him the most value. He isn‚Äôt good enough to be a scorer inside the arc alone and he isn‚Äôt good enough defensively to warrant that being his primary role either.

For Purdue to reach the goals it has for itself this season, it needs Loyer to figure out the shooting woes. In the struggles he has had in previous seasons, it was followed up with a long stretch of elite shooting, There is no reason that can‚Äôt happen again and it needs to happen if Purdue wants to win the B1G title.

Against the Illini, Purdue was very secure with the ball. In fact, it was the 5th consecutive game that Purdue kept their turnovers in single digits. That is the type of ball security CMP has known this team is capable of having with the level of ball handlers it has in Smith, Loyer, Cox, Mayer, Harris, and Benter. In fact, this isn‚Äôt even the longest stretch of this level of security Purdue has had recently.

Last season from the game against UCLA all the way to the first round matchup against High Point, Purdue went six straight games of turnovers in single digits. The Boilers did have a five game stretch in the 2018-2019 and 2011-2012 but their ability to limit turnovers appears to be the best of the CMP era this season.

Since the start of the Keady-era, Purdue has rarely ever gotten through a season where it hasn‚Äôt suffered back to back losses. That has occurred in just 6 total seasons in that forty six year span and shows how difficult the grind of a B1G schedule truly can be. Those seasons were 2023-2024, 2016-2017, 1993-1994, 1989-1990, 1987-1988, and 1986-1987.

On the flipside of that, there have been some rough seasons that Purdue fans have had to endure as well. In the 2005-2006 season, the Boilers were just a bad basketball team that finished 9-19 and lost fifteen of their last eighteen games. Now, what about the worst losing streak for a Boiler squad that made the NCAA tourney? That would go to the 1990-1991 team that lost five straight games and made the tourney as a 7-seed but got beat in the first round by 10th seeded Temple.

Losses happen in long seasons and losing back to back games is more common than you may realize. Even really good teams in Purdue history have lost back to back games but that isn‚Äôt necessarily cause for worry. The key will be how the Boilers continue to use what they learn through the season to find ways to improve and that‚Äôs something this group and this coaching staff have shown a high ability to do.

With his nine points scored, Oscar Cluff surpassed the 1,000 point mark with 1,007 points for his career that has spanned three seasons at Washington State, South Dakota State, and now Purdue. Cluff isn‚Äôt likely to break his single season scoring record of 528 and he isn‚Äôt likely to break any other personal records, but he has been exactly what the Boilers needed (not withstanding the apparent scheme issue that came to a head against UCLA and Illinois).

1Ô∏è‚É£0Ô∏è‚É£0Ô∏è‚É£0Ô∏è‚É£

4th active Boilermaker to reach that mark. pic.twitter.com/XhX7wTASIT

‚Äî Purdue Men's Basketball (@BoilerBall) January 24, 2026

With his twelve assists, Braden Smith now has 943 career assists. That places him twelfth overall just behind Doug Gottleib‚Äôs 947. Smith is now just 133 assists behind Bobby Hurley‚Äôs record with 11 games left. To break the record, here is where he needs to be:

11 games (no post season games): 12.1 assists per game
13 games (2 post season games): 10.23 assists per game
14 games (3 post season games): 9.5 assists per game
15 games (4 post season games): 8.9 assists per game
18 games (7 post season games): 7.4 assists per game
20 games (9 post season games-BTT Final & National Championship): 6.65 assists per game

Braden Smith with a RIDICULOUS pass ü™Ñ

‚Äî NCAA March Madness (@MarchMadnessMBB) January 24, 2026

title: Rams Super Bowl dreams end in Seattle
description: Matthew Stafford was brilliant. Sean McVay was a maestro. And yet, the Los Angeles Rams' season of labor evaporated in a cascade of margins in Seattle.
fullText:
SEATTLE ‚Äî What happens to a dream deferred?

Does it dry up like a raisin in the incessant, mocking Seattle cold?

Does it fester like a wound, salted by the sting of a single yard, a single catch, a single decision in the cruel calculus of a championship game?

Or does it simply sag, a heavy weight on the shoulders of 53 men in blue and gold, as the opposing confetti falls like an alien, hateful snow?

For the Los Angeles Rams, the dream of a return to the summit, of completing a masterful two-year reconstruction, was deferred, denied, and finally extinguished in a 31-27 NFC Championship loss to the Seattle Seahawks.

It was a defeat scripted not by a lack of talent or heart, but by the finest of margins‚Äîthe slivers of error that separate confetti from emptiness.

Matthew Stafford was majestic; he was MVP-esque.

He carved the NFL's top-ranked scoring defense with the precision of a neurosurgeon, completing 22 of 35 passes for 374 yards and three touchdowns.

He threw darts into pinholes, launching seven completions for 226 yards on passes that traveled 20+ air yards‚Äîthe most surrendered by Seattle in a decade.

"He's the MVP of the league," head coach Sean McVay said. "This guy played at a level that's just different."

McVay himself called a luminous game, his play-action designs rendering Seattle's fierce pass rush a step slow, generating 208 yards from deception alone.

For long stretches, the Rams' offense was a symphony of synchronized beauty. Puka Nacua, who had nine receptions for 165 yards and a touchdown, was a force of nature.

Davante Adams turned back the clock with four receptions for 89 yards and a touchdown.

Yet, the symphony ended flat, missing its final, crucial notes.

Football games, particularly championship games, are won in the margins.

You win by capitalizing on every opportunity to extend a lead, especially before halftime, not surrendering it.

Leading 13-10 with 1:33 left in the second quarter, the Rams' offense went three-and-out, a puny, passive series that gifted Seattle 54 seconds.

Sam Darnold‚Äîthe maligned, the itinerant, the USC quarterback whose marred legacy, built by ghastly, past collapses‚Äîmarched the Seahawks 79 yards in six plays.

A touchdown. A 17-13 deficit. A tide turned.

"We had our chances," McVay said. "I thought we got a lot of what we wanted today."

Xavier Smith, reliable all year, let the slick ball slip through his grasp in the third quarter. One play later, Darnold found Jake Bobo for a 17-yard score.

A potential stop became an 11-point hole.

"That was a tough one," McVay said. "You feel like you're going to get some good momentum‚Ä¶ and then they score on the very first play."

The margins are a fourth-down calculus.

Trailing 31-27 with 4:52 left, the Rams faced 4th and 4 at the Seattle 6-yard line.

A field goal makes it a one-point game; however, analytics screamed to go for it.

McVay, the modern evangelist of aggression, listened.

Devon Witherspoon deflected Stafford's pass for Terrence Ferguson, and the Rams walked away with nothing.

And so, the dream of an opportunity to hoist the Lombardi Trophy for the third time in nine years‚Äì‚Äìis deferred.

Now, the questions hang in the Los Angeles air, thick and urgent.

Where do the Rams go from here?

How do they bolster a secondary that proved porous over the season's latter half, a unit torched for 153 yards by Jaxon Smith-Njigba alone?

How do they reinforce a linebacking corps that, at times, was outmatched in coverage and containment?

The labor to craft this contender was Herculean. There is no assurance of a return.

The NFC landscape offers no solace.

Seattle, with Mike Macdonald's defensive genius, has the makings of a sustained beast.

Chicago's offense buds with terrifying potential.

Philadelphia simmers, a quarterback adjustment away.

San Francisco, if it can ever stanch its injury plague, remains a monster.

And on the other side stood Sam Darnold.

Everyone must now rewrite the narrative of his career‚Äîthat he folds and crumples under pressure.

Darnold completed 25 of 36 for 346 yards and three touchdowns.

He stood resolute, becoming the first USC quarterback to start a Super Bowl.

"It's amazing," Darnold said. "To be able to do it with these guys‚Ä¶ that's why it means the world to me."

In the Rams' silent locker room, the dream lay not exploded, but deflated.

Stafford's brilliance, McVay's mastery‚Äîboth rendered artifacts of a path not taken.

Langston Hughes' poem asks what happens to a dream deferred.

On this night, the Rams live the answer: it doesn't explode. It just slowly, painfully, drains away, leaving only the hard questions of an endless offseason and the haunting vision of what might have been, one yard, one catch, one decision away.

title: Steve Kerr talks 'bizarre, sad' win over Timberwolves after latest ICE fatal shooting: 'Their group was suffering'
description: "It was one of the most bizarre, sad games I‚Äôve ever been a part of."
fullText:
The mood inside the Target Center was, understandably, off on Sunday afternoon.

While the Golden State Warriors did roll to a near-30-point blowout over the Minnesota Timberwolves, it wasn‚Äôt the game that threw the vibes off. It was everything else going on just outside of the arena doors on the streets of Minneapolis that did it.

That, Warriors head coach Steve Kerr said after the Warriors' 111-85 win, was very apparent.

‚ÄúHonestly what I felt was that their group was suffering,‚Äù Kerr said, via ESPN‚Äôs Anthony Slater. ‚ÄúI thought the vibe in the stands, it was one of the most bizarre, sad games I‚Äôve ever been a part of. You could feel the somber atmosphere. Their team, we could tell, they were struggling with everything that‚Äôs been going on and what the city has been through.

‚ÄúIt was very sad. It was a sad night.‚Äù

Steve Kerr called the arena atmosphere in Minneapolis today one of the most ‚Äúbizarre, sad‚Äù vibes he‚Äôs experienced at a game

Warriors blew out the Timberwolves. 

‚ÄúHonestly what I felt was that their group was suffering.‚Äù pic.twitter.com/K1EsR6Fr8j

‚Äî Anthony Slater (@anthonyVslater) January 26, 2026

Sunday‚Äôs game was initially supposed to be held on Saturday, but the league quickly pushed it 24 hours in the wake of the fatal shooting of 37-year-old Veterans Affairs nurse Alex Pretti by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents. That came just weeks after an ICE agent shot and killed 37-year-old Renee Good elsewhere in the city. Those shootings, as well as larger ICE operations and activity throughout the Twin Cities region, have sparked massive protests and demonstrations.

Plenty in the sports world have spoken out, including several Minnesota sports teams and the National Basketball Players Association. New York Liberty star and Unrivaled co-founder Breanna Stewart held an ‚ÄúAbolish ICE‚Äù sign before her game on Sunday. Former Timberwolves star Karl-Anthony Towns and Indiana Pacers star Tyrese Haliburton both posted about it on social media.

After seeing the situation unfold, both Kerr and Timberwolves coach Chris Finch were in agreement. Playing basketball on Saturday, Finch said, ‚Äújust didn‚Äôt feel like the right thing to do.‚Äù

Here is Chris Finch's opening statement prior to his pregame media availability on the shooting in Minneapolis on Saturday.

"For the second time in less than three weeks, we've lost another member of our community in the most unimaginable way." pic.twitter.com/mWRhBchC3W

‚Äî Dane Moore (@DaneMooreNBA) January 25, 2026

‚ÄúFor the second time in less than three weeks, we‚Äôve lost another beloved member of our community in the most unimaginable way,‚Äù an emotional Finch said before the game.

‚ÄúAs an organization, we are heartbroken for what we are having to witness and endure and watch. We just want to extend our thoughts, prayers and concern for Mr. Pretti‚Äôs family, all the loved ones and everyone involved in such an unconscionable situation in a community that we really love, full of people who are, by nature, peaceful and prideful. We just stand in support of our great community here.‚Äù

Warriors star Stephen Curry said he was ‚Äúglued‚Äù to the TV on Friday and Saturday when they weren‚Äôt playing or practicing. He also said he has videos on his phone that he took of protesters who were walking through the streets on Friday outside of their hotel in sub-zero temperatures.

‚ÄúThe protests that were going on downtown, it was amazing to watch the turnout,‚Äù Curry said. ‚ÄúThe peaceful protests and unified voice that was here, you feel like that would kind of turn the tide to a more positive direction. Then you wake up in the morning and you see what happened ‚Ä¶ There's a lot of change that needs to happen, and when you‚Äôre here, you feel it.‚Äù

The Timberwolves held a moment of silence for Pretti before the game on Sunday. Several in the crowd shouted out ‚ÄúF*** ICE‚Äù during the moment.

Moment of silence held for Alex Pretti before today‚Äôs game. pic.twitter.com/qzbAVlFxVh

‚Äî Chris Hine (@ChristopherHine) January 25, 2026

While there were protests outside of the Target Center again on Sunday, the game went off as planned without any issues.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very difficult to see so many people struggling and sad,‚Äù Kerr said. ‚ÄúThey came to the game to try to forget about stuff, I guess, but I don‚Äôt think anything went away for the city and for their team. I think they were suffering from the effects of everything.‚Äù

title: Champion Keys dumped out in last 16 as Melbourne braces for heatwave
description: Jessica Pegula sent reigning champion and podcast co-host Madison Keys spinning out of the Australian Open on Monday while Jannik Sinner aims to avoid the same fate and reach the quarter-finals in stifling heat.Later Monday, reigning champion Sinner -- who struggles in the heat -- will be strong favourite against fellow Italian Luciano Darderi.
fullText:
Jessica Pegula sent reigning champion and podcast co-host Madison Keys spinning out of the Australian Open on Monday while Jannik Sinner aims to avoid the same fate and reach the quarter-finals in stifling heat.

In temperatures approaching 30C in Melbourne, fifth seed Lorenzo Musetti set up a last-eight showdown with Novak Djokovic.

Keys and Pegula launched day nine in a clash at Rod Laver Arena between two Americans who know each other well.

They are good friends and also host a tennis podcast together, "The Player's Box", and had even been planning to record an episode on the eve of their match.

All that was put aside as a clinical Pegula dominated 6-3, 6-4 to set up a last-eight encounter with another American in fourth seed Amanda Anisimova.

Anisimova, beaten finalist at last year's US Open and Wimbledon, cooled herself off with bags of ice before taming China's Wang Xinyu 7-6 (7/4), 6-4.

Pegula, the 31-year-old sixth seed, is chasing an elusive Grand Slam title, her best performance to date reaching the US Open final in 2024.

An erratic Keys made 27 unforced errors to Pegula's 17 and fired down six double faults as her title defence ended in the last 16.

The forfeit, as a part of a jokey bet with Pegula, will be a slice of apple pie with melted cheddar cheese on top.

"A bet is a bet, so I'll do it. I hope it's less gross than I think it's going to be, but we will find out," said Keys, who described herself as proud despite defeat.

Also in the women's draw in the fourth round, fifth seed Elena Rybakina plays 21st seed Elise Mertens of Belgium.

Second seed Iga Swiatek will be heavy favourite against Maddison Inglis.

Australian qualifier Inglis, ranked 168, features on Rod Laver Arena in the biggest match of her life.

The 28-year-old was given free passage into the last 16 when two-time Melbourne champion Naomi Osaka pulled out injured.

After sizzling weather caused the suspension of matches on Saturday, temperatures are rising sharply again.

Longer matches on Monday will have 10-minute breaks in certain circumstances as part of measures to protect player health.

Temperatures are forecast to hit a blistering 44C on Tuesday, meaning matches are likely to be played under roofs on the three courts that have them.

Later Monday, reigning champion Sinner ‚Äî who struggles in the heat ‚Äî will be strong favourite against fellow Italian Luciano Darderi.

Darderi, the 22nd seed, has never made it this far at a Grand Slam while Sinner is chasing a third Australian Open crown in a row.

Only Djokovic has done that in the Open era.

Melbourne Park king Djokovic was supposed to play the 20-year-old Jakub Mensik in a night match.

But the Czech player pulled out injured on Sunday, sending 10-time champion Djokovic into the last eight without hitting a ball.

The 38-year-old Serb will play Musetti after the Italian defeated American ninth seed Taylor Fritz 6-2, 7-5, 6-4.

In the last match of the day on centre court, United States eighth seed Ben Shelton plays Norway's 12th seed Casper Ruud in the timeslot when Djokovic was supposed to be on court.

title: Stephen Curry Shares Worrying Injury Update After Historic NBA Achievement Against Timberwolves
description: While Minnesota is supercharged with emotions, Stephen Curry demonstrated physical grit of his own. Before he lent heartfelt support to the grieving community that‚Äôs rattled by the death of Alex Pretti on Saturday (the day the game was originally scheduled for), Curry led the Warriors to a 111-85 win.
fullText:
While Minnesota is supercharged with emotions, Stephen Curry demonstrated physical grit of his own. Before he lent heartfelt support to the grieving community that‚Äôs rattled by the death of Alex Pretti on Saturday (the day the game was originally scheduled for), Curry led the Warriors to a 111-85 win. All while powering through injuries, getting hurt again, and adding another historic knotch to his resume.

Curry revealed he was following the goings-on in Minnesota while he spent Saturday resting his knee after the game was cancelled. He was listed as questionable before Sunday‚Äôs rescheduled game. But he played 28 minutes and was instrumental in the Dubs‚Äô turnaround. Another player stepped on his toe, but that didn‚Äôt seem to slow him down.

Given the circumstances, the Dubs and Wolves have a back-to-back rematch tomorrow. When asked if he would be available tomorrow, Curry said, ‚ÄúIf everything goes well, yeah. With the recovery and all that, the minutes tonight weren‚Äôt crazy, so hopefully I respond well.‚Äù

When the Golden State Warriors landed in Minnesota yesterday, some of the players got their workouts in before the game was canceled. The point guard hurt his knee during that. ‚ÄúKind of something flared up yesterday when we came over to get a workout in. It was super weird,‚Äù he revealed.

But his personal injury update is a lot more concerning when he reveals some persistent issues. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve had stuff going on with quads and whatnot, but it was something that I hadn‚Äôt felt before. So, I definitely took advantage of the day off to get right, but hopefully that continues.‚Äù

After Jimmy Butler‚Äôs season-ending ACL tear, followed by Jonathan Kuminga‚Äôs indefinite break for bone bruising, the last thing Dub Nation can deal with is an injured Steph. Tomorrow De‚ÄôAnthony Melton and Al Horford sit out for injury management and fans wouldn‚Äôt mind if Steph joined them. Moving up the all-time scoring ladder can wait a little longer.

Despite battling injuries, Stephen Curry had an impressive 26 points, 2 rebounds, 7 assists, and 4 steals. That alone carried him to the 19th spot on the NBA‚Äôs All-time Scoring list. He passed John Havlicek and tied Paul Pierce for cracking the top 20 with 26,397 points in his career.

He‚Äôs only 99 points away from catching up to Tim Duncan next. So far this season, Curry has averaged 27.3 points, 5.0 assists, and 3.7 rebounds while shooting 46.8% from the field and 39.8% from the arc.

Analysts predict he‚Äôd crack top 10 soon enough. They, in fact, think he would‚Äôve done it a long time ago had it not been for his injury history that also kept him underpaid for a period of time.

Tonight, Curry limped during the empty moments and yet he carried the offense. If he aggravates what is now a sore knee and ends up missing more than one game, the Warriors‚Äô offense will be diminished.

For now even Steve Kerr is hopeful that Curry will be cleared to play. Steph is still listed as questionable for Monday and they‚Äôve left his status as a game-time decision.

The post Stephen Curry Shares Worrying Injury Update After Historic NBA Achievement Against Timberwolves appeared first on EssentiallySports.

title: Joshua Van Unfazed by Manel Kape‚Äôs Fiery Response After UFC 324 Result Costs Him a Major Rematch
description: UFC 324 did more than just try to reshuffle the flyweight rankings; it also revived old grudges and established new ones overnight. One knockout in the prelims sent shockwaves across the division, and the fallout quickly spread on social media.
fullText:
UFC 324 did more than just try to reshuffle the flyweight rankings; it also revived old grudges and established new ones overnight. One knockout in the prelims sent shockwaves across the division, and the fallout quickly spread on social media. What should have been a quiet night for the champion Joshua Van, watching the fight at home, evolved into a digital sparring match, revealing exactly how heated the title picture has become.

For ‚ÄòThe Fearless,‚Äô the timing was almost too perfect. As fans processed Charles Johnson‚Äòs defeat at UFC 324, the champion casually shared a tweet that cut harder than it looked. With a laughing emoji and a simple caption, a long-awaited rematch wasn‚Äôt just delayed‚Äîit felt erased.

Joshua Van‚Äôs tweet wasn‚Äôt subtle. ‚ÄúUhh ohh, there goes the rematch

,‚Äù he wrote, a direct dig at Charles Johnson‚Äîthe only man to knock him out in the UFC. Given their history, it felt like a reminder: momentum is vital, and timing can be cruel. Johnson had spent months suggesting that he still found flaws in Van‚Äôs game.

But UFC 324 effectively sealed that door that led to the rematch, at least for the time being. That‚Äôs when Manel Kape joined the chat. Clearly furious, ‚ÄòStaryboy‚Äô denied any suggestion that Van was looking past him, arguing that the champion only got to this point because he stepped in during Kape‚Äôs injury absence.

In a fiery tweet, he wrote, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt forget this: you‚Äôre only in this position because I broke my foot and you replaced me against Brandon Royval. Everyone saw what happened once I came back from injury.‚Äù He further added, ‚ÄúSo stop this rematch bulls‚Äî. He knocked u out cold; there is no rematch. You‚Äôre fighting me. Give me four weeks. That‚Äôs all I need to put u back in diapers.‚Äù

Van‚Äôs response? He didn‚Äôt bite emotionally; he corrected the record. ‚ÄúShut up u didn‚Äôt wanna sign the contract

,‚Äù he replied dismissively. And honestly, his version checks out. As per reports, after UFC 324 lost its original co-headliner between women‚Äôs bantamweight champion Kayla Harrison and Amanda Nunes, Van got the call.

And while the champion refused to confirm or deny it, he did hint that Kape turned down a fight against him at some point. He told MMA Junkie. ‚ÄúAsk him. He would know. Last time I checked, the champ said yes, and the challenger said no.‚Äù The 24-year-old further added, ‚ÄúOne guy is running.‚Äù

While UFC 324 did not crown his next opponent, it did clarify one thing: ‚ÄòThe Fearless‚Äô is not seeking validation. He‚Äôs watching the division sort itself out and waiting for someone to volunteer. And if Manel Kape is to be believed, he is ready for the fight and has a lot planned for the title fight already.

That confidence Joshua Van has been projecting is exactly what Manel Kape seems to be feeding off. Unlike ‚ÄòThe Fearless,‚Äô who has chosen to be more measured, Kape has taken the opposite approach by being loud, dismissive, and certain that this matchup will end one way. In his opinion, this is not a debate about contenders or timing. It‚Äôs a stylistic mismatch waiting to be exposed.

‚ÄòStarboy‚Äô did not mince words when talking about Joshua Van to MMA Junkie. He pitched the potential title bout as routine business rather than a challenge, relying primarily on the idea that Van‚Äôs striking plays into his hands. Kape believes his current run of knockouts has already revealed the disparity, claiming that even high-volume competitors were unable to touch him once he found his groove.

To him, Van represents movement without consequence. ‚ÄúTo be honest, I see Joshua Van as a punching bag. For my fight, I think I only have to go to the gym and punch the bag. That‚Äôs the fight that I‚Äôm going to have. A hard punching bag. What I‚Äôm going to land whatever I want. Of course, this punching bag is going to throw something, but I‚Äôm going to avoid.‚Äù

What makes Manel Kape‚Äôs pitch interesting isn‚Äôt the trash talk, but the conviction behind it. He‚Äôs promising control wrapped in violence, a mano-o-mano that looks exciting but is ultimately one-sided. In fact, even the date or location doesn‚Äôt seem to matter much to him either. He says all the promotion has to do is pick the date and send the contract.

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs go March 8 [at UFC 326],‚Äù Kape suggested. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the date. But I don‚Äôt mind to fight in Houston. I don‚Äôt mind to be a title [fight] co-main event. I know this doesn‚Äôt happen, but I don‚Äôt mind this.‚Äù The question of whether that confidence is prophetic or premature remains unanswered. But one thing is certain: if this fight takes place, Manel Kape‚Äôs side will be full of belief, and that alone ensures fans that the tension will keep on building.

The post Joshua Van Unfazed by Manel Kape‚Äôs Fiery Response After UFC 324 Result Costs Him a Major Rematch appeared first on EssentiallySports.

title: Will Patriots Make NFL History In Super Bowl Vs. Seahawks?
description: After edging the Denver Broncos 10-7 in the AFC Championship Game on Sunday, the New England Patriots are Super Bowl-bound. Again. This marks the 10th Super Bowl appearance for the Patriots in the last 25 seasons and their 12th in franchise history. New England has won six championships so far, all with Tom Brady and [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
After edging the Denver Broncos 10-7 in the AFC Championship Game on Sunday, the New England Patriots are Super Bowl-bound.

This marks the 10th Super Bowl appearance for the Patriots in the last 25 seasons and their 12th in franchise history. New England has won six championships so far, all with Tom Brady and Bill Belichick.

If the Patriots get their seventh Super Bowl win in two weeks, it will be the most in NFL history, breaking a tie with the Pittsburgh Steelers. Their 12 appearances are already a record.

The Steelers also have six Lombardi Trophies, with their most recent one coming during the 2008 campaign. Four of their rings came during the 1970s, however, so New England has been the far more successful franchise recently.

Patriots 

Last 25 years 

Have more than 2X the amount of Super Bowl appearances as the next 2 teams COMBINED 

1. Patriots ‚Äì 10

2. Chiefs ‚Äì 5
3. Eagles ‚Äì 4

Domination pic.twitter.com/ytHekrXraG

‚Äî bostonsportsinf (@jsgiii22661) January 25, 2026

Pittsburgh hasn‚Äôt even won a playoff game since early 2017. losing seven straight postseason games. The Patriots have reached four Super Bowls and won two during that time.

While New England has NFL history at stake, so does its head coach, Mike Vrabel. A three-time Super Bowl champ with the Patriots as a player, he has a chance to become the first person in NFL history to win a Super Bowl as a player and a coach with the same franchise.

To do that, they‚Äôll have to go through the Seattle Seahawks, who are out for revenge after narrowly losing their last Super Bowl appearance to New England on Malcolm Butler‚Äôs goal-line interception 11 years ago. The Seahawks will have to overcome that painful history along with Sam Darnold‚Äôs embarrassing 0-4 career record against the Patriots.

Darnold will need to step up against New England‚Äôs historically good defense, which is averaging just 8.7 points per game allowed in these playoffs. Meanwhile, the Patriots have already beaten three elite defenses this postseason, so there‚Äôs no reason they can‚Äôt defeat another.

Sam Darnold‚Äôs Mind‚ÄëBoggling Stat Vs. Patriots Could Tip Super Bowl Toward New England

title: Jessica Pegula reveals special motivation behind beating Madison Keys as defending Australian Open champion exits
description: Pegula, whose parents own the Buffalo Bills, avoided wearing a Kansas City Chiefs jersey as a forfeit after setting up a quarter-final with Amanda Anisimova
fullText:
Jessica Pegula avoided wearing a Kansas City Chiefs jersey as she defeated Madison Keys to end her fellow podcast host‚Äôs Australia Open title defence.

Pegula will play another American in fourth seed Amanda Anisimova in the quarter-finals after reaching the last-eight in Melbourne for the fourth time.

The 31-year-old sixth seed is good friends with Keys, who won her first grand slam title at the Australian Open last year, and they host The Player's Box podcast together along with Jennifer Brady and Desirae Krawczyk.

They recorded an episode before their fourth-round match, and decided the winner would choose a forfeit for the loser.

Keys decided that if she won, Pegula, whose parents own the NFL team the Buffalo Bills, would have had to wear a Chiefs jersey with Travis Kelce and Taylor Swift on the back.

In ensuring she avoided wearing the colours of the source of Buffalo‚Äôs recent post-season woes, Pegula will instead make Keys eat an apple pie topped with melted cheese.

‚ÄúI had a lot of motivation today,‚Äù Pegula said after her 6-3 6-4 victory over Keys, with the pair remaining in good spirits as they were seen chatting in the gym post-match as Pegula avoided the forfeit.

‚ÄúThat was bad," said Pegula. "She was, like, 'Mine's worse'. I was, like, 'What are you talking about? My family owns the Bills. This team has owned us in the post-season'.

‚ÄúAll she has to do is eat a piece of pie. What is the big deal? I think that was really some extra motivation, because that would have been a tough moment for me.‚Äù

Pegula said the apple pie topped with cheddar cheese was her family's Thanksgiving tradition.

"A bet is a bet, so I'll do it," said Keys. "I hope it's less gross than I think it's going to be, but we will find out, I guess."

Keys, meanwhile, is set to drop out of the world‚Äôs top 10 after her fourth-round exit but said she was proud of how she had handle the experience of returning as defending champion.

‚ÄúIt's obviously not the way that I wanted things to end here, but I'm still really proud of myself,‚Äù Keys said

‚ÄúI think coming back, being defending champion, dealing with all of the extra pressure and nerves, I'm just really proud of myself for how I handled it.

‚ÄúJust one of those days where I feel like Jess beat me, and I can kind of walk away with my head held high.‚Äù

Pegula is bidding to win her first grand slam title, having coming closest at the US Open with an appearance in the final and semi-finals in the last two seasons.

But she is yet to drop a set so far and will be confident when she meets another US Open runner-up in Anisimova, who is bidding to win her first grand slam title after defeats in the finals of Wimbledon and the US Open last season.

‚ÄúI'm just really happy that the work that I've done with my coaches,‚Äù Pegula said. ‚ÄúI really believe in that and what we have done, and to be able to kind of execute that stuff in a grand slam, second tournament of the year for me, will give me a lot of confidence, not just here but just going into the year.

‚ÄúI have always been the type of player where I get frustrated when I feel like I'm not getting better. And I still think that at my age, I've already had a lot of really great results. Being 31, I still feel like I'm improving as a player. So that is what gets me the most excited.‚Äù

title: Major competition undergoes sudden change as catastrophic threat looms over venue: 'Some of the most significant ‚Ä¶ we have seen'
description: It‚Äôs not the first time it has had to account for intolerable weather conditions.
fullText:
Worldwide, heat waves are becoming less unusual. It's no longer possible to ignore sweltering summer temperatures or to dismiss them as one-off anomalies.

According to The New York Times, the Australian Open tennis tournament, scheduled for the second half of January amid peak summer weather in the Southern Hemisphere, has been forced to rearrange some of its matches and adjust court assignments in anticipation of 100-degree afternoon temperatures in Melbourne.

The tournament has shifted its morning start time earlier by an hour, making room for an additional match in Margaret Court Arena ‚Äî one of only three available indoor courts.

It's not the first time the Australian Open has had to account for intolerable weather conditions. In 2019, per the Times, the tournament introduced a "Heat Stress Scale" to account for "the four climate factors ‚Äî air temperature, radiant heat or the strength of the sun, humidity, and wind speed ‚Äî which affect a player's ability to disperse heat from their body."

In addition to being unbearable for athletes active at the time, these high summer temperatures are symptomatic of a climate that's changing for the worse.

South Australia fire chief Brett Loughlin told the Guardian that the recent temperature extremes rank among "some of the most significant fire weather forecasts we have seen in South Australia in recent years."

Warm summers and isolated weather phenomena on their own may not be much cause for concern, but their mounting severity in recent decades points to a broader pattern. Human activity is the principal driving force behind our current climate crisis, with industrial and residential greenhouse gas trapping heat within our atmosphere as our natural carbon sinks ‚Äî that is, oceans and forests ‚Äî fall victim to pollution and urbanization.

While Australia endures a torrid summer, much of the Northern Hemisphere is experiencing an abnormally warm, dry winter. Meanwhile, the occasional extreme cold snap ‚Äî contrary to popular belief ‚Äî is just another way in which the climate catastrophe can manifest, as Arctic melting temporarily shifts the bitterly cold polar vortex southward.

The Australian Open may be moving tennis schedules to accommodate this alarming heat, but our warming climate has begun affecting athletes and nonathletes around the world ‚Äî and likely will for decades to come. New carbon capture technologies and efforts to preserve the longevity of our forests and oceans can go a long way, but in the end, it's collective action that can make a real difference.

For your part, try taking public transit instead of your private combustion vehicle to work every day. Consider upgrading your appliances to energy-efficient alternatives or even installing an eco-friendly solar energy system. Even though it may not seem like much, individual choices do add up for the better.

What's the most you'd pay per month to put solar panels on your roof if there was no down payment?

I'd only do it if someone else paid for it

Click your choice to see results and speak your mind.

Get TCD's free newsletters for easy tips to save more, waste less, and make smarter choices ‚Äî and earn up to $5,000 toward clean upgrades in TCD's exclusive Rewards Club.

title: Wrexham's Rathbone with a goal ratio to rival the best
description: Ollie Rathbone says Wrexham's QPR comeback showed why they are a play-off contender ‚Äì just as he showed why he is rivalling the very best in front of goal.  Rathbone reckons the 3-2 win at Loftus Road typified the mentality Phil Parkinson has built in the Red Dragons' dressing room.  It is the fourth league goal this season for Rathbone who missed the first three months of the campaign after a pre-season ankle injury.
fullText:
Ollie Rathbone says Wrexham's QPR comeback showed why they are a play-off contender ‚Äì just as he showed why he is rivalling the very best in front of goal.

Rathbone reckons the 3-2 win at Loftus Road typified the mentality Phil Parkinson has built in the Red Dragons' dressing room.

But it was the 29-year-old midfielder who the fans were serenading loudest in west London after his injury-time winner.

It is the fourth league goal this season for Rathbone who missed the first three months of the campaign after a pre-season ankle injury.

And that is despite playing just 266 minutes in the Championship, with two league starts and seven appearances off the bench.

It means Rathbone has averaged a goal every 67 minutes of league action ‚Äì far outstripping the rest of the Championship top scorers.

It was Wrexham boss Phil Parkinson who highlighted his goals-per-minute ratio as he heaped on praise for Rathbone and fellow goalscorer Josh Windass.

But Rathbone himself insisted it was what the result meant for the team that was of more importance, saying: "It was a difficult start to the season for me, it felt I was playing catch up a little bit but now I'm feeling good and loving being part of this group.

"We had great run over Christmas with four wins in a row and we were all keen to show it wasn't a flash in the pan.

"So after a rocky week and up against it at 2-1 down, to get the win is amazing."

The away win came after coming unstuck at the Cae Ras in successive fixtures, first losing against Norwich before conceding in the last minute to draw with Leicester.

"I think it shows a lot about the group and the mentality that we were really disappointed with drawing with Leicester who have been Premier League Champions and FA Cup winners not so long ago," Rathbone said.

"It was a kick in the teeth and we were kicking ourselves for throwing away two points and then, with five minutes to go [at QPR] we're looking at the clock with a similar feeling.

"But I thought then we showed why we're in the position we are in the league."

The win moved Wrexham into the top six for the first time since promotion to this level, but although Rathbone admitted the game could prove a significant moment, he added: "If you get carried away you can easily fall down the table.

"But for now we're in a great place, the team's in a really good spirits, the group's together, and it's really enjoyable to be part of."

title: Seahawks News: Mike Macdonald Says Sam Darnold ‚ÄúShut a Lot of People Up‚Äù With 3-TD Game vs. Rams
description: Once the No. 3 overall pick in the 2018 NFL Draft, Sam Darnold‚Äôs career seemed destined to be remembered as a cautionary tale.
fullText:
Once the No. 3 overall pick in the 2018 NFL Draft, Sam Darnold‚Äôs career seemed destined to be remembered as a cautionary tale. He was labeled a bust with the New York Jets, flamed out in Carolina, faded into the background in San Francisco, and was ultimately discarded by the Minnesota Vikings. Eight seasons later, that narrative is officially dead.

On Sunday night, Darnold delivered the defining performance of his career, throwing for 346 yards and three touchdowns to lead the Seattle Seahawks to a 31‚Äì27 win over the Los Angeles Rams in the NFC Championship Game. The victory sends Seattle to Super Bowl LX. And sends Darnold‚Äôs critics scrambling.

‚ÄúI mean, he just shut a lot of people up tonight,‚Äù Seahawks head coach Mike Macdonald said after the game. ‚ÄúSo I‚Äôm really happy for him.‚Äù

Darnold was sensational from start to finish, matching throws with MVP candidate Matthew Stafford on the game‚Äôs biggest stage. He connected with Jaxon Smith-Njigba for a momentum-swinging touchdown with 20 seconds left in the first half, flipping the game in Seattle‚Äôs favor.

Following a disastrous Rams special teams mistake, Darnold capitalized by firing a strike to Jake Bobo over the middle for another score. Later, he ripped a perfectly placed spiral through Los Angeles‚Äô zone coverage to Cooper Kupp for a 13-yard touchdown, the play that ultimately proved decisive.

The performance was a masterclass in poise and precision. Darnold finished 25-of-36 passing with zero interceptions, repeatedly delivering when the moment demanded it most.

Seattle complemented Darnold‚Äôs brilliance with timely defense and game-changing special teams. Devon Witherspoon made back-to-back pass breakups inside the six-yard line late in the fourth quarter, forcing a turnover on downs that kept the Rams off the scoreboard.

On special teams, the Seahawks forced two muffed punts from Rams returner Xavier Smith, recovering the second to set up Darnold‚Äôs touchdown pass to Bobo.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a team win,‚Äù Macdonald said. ‚ÄúAnd then, you can‚Äôt talk about the game without talking about our quarterback.‚Äù

For Darnold, this marks his first NFC Championship win as a starter. He previously earned a conference title as a backup with the 49ers during their Super Bowl run two years ago, but this one was different ‚Äî this one was his.

After five teams, nearly 3,000 pass attempts, and almost eight full seasons in the league, Darnold has become the first quarterback from the vaunted 2018 draft class, which included Baker Mayfield and MVPs Josh Allen and Lamar Jackson, to win a conference championship as a starter.

When his best was required, Sam Darnold delivered it. Two weeks from now in Santa Clara, he‚Äôll have a chance to put the final stamp on a career resurrection that once seemed impossible.

The post Seahawks News: Mike Macdonald Says Sam Darnold ‚ÄúShut a Lot of People Up‚Äù With 3-TD Game vs. Rams appeared first on The SportsRush.

title: Is the Australian Open on TV? Channel, live stream and how to watch tennis grand slam
description: Jannik Sinner and Madison Keys are the defending champions as the opening grand slam of the year gets underway in Melbourne
fullText:
The Australian Open kicks off the tennis grand slams in 2026 as Jannik Sinner returns as defending champion and Aryna Sabalenka bids to regain her crown.

Sinner will be attempting to become just the second man in the Open era, after Novak Djokovic, to win three Australian Open singles titles in a row, while women‚Äôs No 1 Sabalenka will be determined after Madison Keys ended her bid for a hat-trick in last year‚Äôs final.

Two players will enter the tournament with the mission of completing the career grand slam. Both Carlos Alcaraz and Iga Swiatek are an Australian Open title away from having won all four of the major titles - Alcaraz would be the youngest man to achieve the feat if he does so this year.

After competing in the finals of the French Open, Wimbledon and US Open last season, Melbourne is the only one of the major stages where Alcaraz and Sinner are yet to meet.

Djokovic and Rafael Nadal were the last men to play in four grand slam finals in a row, which came between the 2011 Wimbledon and the 2012 French Open.

Here‚Äôs everything you need to know:

The tournament will be shown live on TNT Sports in the UK as well as online on Discovery+.

In the US, it will be shown live on ESPN and Tennis Channel.

The second round of the tournament begins on Wednesday 21 January. Finals weekend is across Saturday 31 January and Sunday 1 February. Here‚Äôs the latest order of play.

What is the Australian Open prize money?

The prize fund for this year's Australian Open has been increased by 16 per cent to ¬£55.4m, making it the largest purse in the tournament's history.

The two singles champions will each pocket ¬£2.1m, up from the ¬£1.7m which Jannik Sinner and Madison Keys took home last year.

title: Record holder Stockley targets Hyrox World Champs
description: Welsh PE teacher Lauren Stockley is targeting a sport at the 2026 Hyrox World Championships
fullText:
"I just love a challenge really, that's my problem."

Welsh PE teacher Lauren Stockley draws a smile as she plots out another busy year.

Not content with just heading to the Ironman 70.3 World Championships in Nice in September, she has her sights set on more Hyrox glory.

For those unfamiliar, Hyrox is a global fitness racing competition designed to test an athlete's endurance and strength.

It has become hugely popular and last year thousands descended on Cardiff for a three-day event at the Principality Stadium.

Stockley, 26, has proved a natural talent. A little over a year after completing her first Hyrox, she was part of a quartet who set a women's world record in London in December 2025.

How Hyrox became the latest sporting craze

Hyrox: The new fitness trend sweeping the capital

Hyrox comprises of 8km of running with eight exercise stations in between.

Competitors endure 1km on a standing ski machine, 50m sled push, 50m sled pull, 80m burpee jumps, 1km indoor rowing, 200m kettlebell carry, 100m sandbag lunges, and to finish, 100 throws and catches of a medicine ball.

"I've always been involved in sport in my whole life really," Stockley said.

"I was a competitive swimmer and runner from a young age.

"When I went to university I enjoyed a lot of hockey but after that I got into a bit of CrossFit, so I've sort of done everything.

"With CrossFit I enjoyed the Olympic lifting but it compromised my running quite a bit and that's when I saw Hyrox as this big fitness event and thought I'd like to give that a go."

Stockley's Hyrox debut came at an open event in Birmingham with her performance earning her qualification for the World Championships in Chicago.

"I was like 'right I actually need to do a bit of training for this,'" she said.

"I did first pro in Glasgow, the weights increased and I won that in my age group.

"I was fifth in my age group at World Champs in 2025 and it's been going in a nice trajectory ever since."

In her first year of professional Hyrox races, Stockley could have been forgiven for easing herself into the sport, but by the year's end she had set a world record alongside Alexandra Hill, Saskia Geddes and Allana Falconer.

"I'd met them before but we'd never actually raced together so we were sort of put together in this team," Stockley recalled.

"It was never an aim for us [to set a world record]. We were always going to give it a good go, it was the last race of London Hyrox, so it was like, 'right let's do this.'

"We looked up at the board and said 'oh my gosh I think this is a world record', it was a surprise but we went as hard as we could.

"Once we'd finished I think the realisation set in and the announcer realised 'oh my God this is a world record'".

Stockley is now preparing for the Elite 15 competition in Phoenix, Arizona which serves as one of four Hyrox majors.

The State Farm Stadium, home to NFL's Arizona Cardinals, will serve as host for the event, with Stockley competing in the singles on 29 January before returning two days later for the age group doubles.

The top three finishers at each earn automatic qualification to June's World Championships in Sweden.

Stockley says competition will be fierce.

"To be with those top girls, they're running under that hour mark so that's definitely a goal," she said.

title: Kenneth Walker III, Jaxon Smith-Njigba lead list of Big Ten stars in Super Bowl 60
description: The Super Bowl is set between the Seattle Seahawks and the New England Patriots, and there is plenty of Big Ten star power on both teams, but most are arguably in Seattle.
fullText:
Kenneth Walker III, Jaxon Smith-Njigba lead list of Big Ten stars in Super Bowl 60 originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The Super Bowl between the Seattle Seahawks and New England Patriots has a chance to be one of the best in recent memory. As such, it is a prime opportunity for some former Big Ten stars to show out on one of the biggest stages in sports.

More specifically, among the Seahawks, four former Big Ten players stand out, each with a uniquely different path to where they are today. Those would be Seahawks running back Kenneth Walker III, wide receiver Jaxon Smith-Njigba, cornerback Devon Witherspoon and quarterback Sam Darnold.

For those who may have forgotten, Smith-Njigba was a one-man show at Ohio State with an electrifying offensive presence around him. In 2021, he had a breakout season for the Buckeyes with 1,606 receiving yards and nine touchdowns.

Meanwhile, Walker III was as reliable as ever on Michigan State teams that were a far cry from what fans in the mid-2010s were used to. In his one season with Michigan State before heading off to the NFL, he scored 19 total touchdowns

MORE:¬†Jaxon Smith-Njigba joins elite club with absurd record in Seahawks-Rams NFC Championship

Now he's duplicating his collegiate success in the NFLas he scored a touchdown in Sunday's NFC Championship en route to a 31-27 win against the Los Angeles Rams.

Signaling out the many accolades that make Darnold one of the NFL's best comeback stories in recent memory, the fact that he is the first-ever ex-USC Trojan set to start a Super Bowl is truly remarkable.

Concerning Witherspoon, it just goes to show that Illinois coach Bret Bielema's model of "sustained success" and wearing the developmental program mantra with pride is what makes Witherspoon's success story as memorable as ever.

In fact, he may just be the unsung hero who put the Seahawks in a position to win to begin with.

Nonetheless, all four stars are just four of a select few that will have a chance to make their mark on NFL history for years to come.

MORE:¬†Why Fernando Mendoza would be 'so grateful' to be selected by 'any team' in NFL draft

In 12 days, we'll see how far they come.
